title: The Secret To Enjoying A Hobby? Half-Ass It
text:
The Secret To Enjoying A Hobby? Half-Ass It

The moment I stepped into adulthood, my after-school routine of endless dance and drama classes fell entirely by the wayside. Instead, once I started working full time, Iâ€™d go to the pub and then head home for my all important looking-at-phone-in-bed time.

This summer though, I finally decided to dip my toe back into the world of organized fun by casually taking up yoga with the intention of simply helping myself unwind in a healthy way. My semi-regular relationship with the activity means that I still set up my mat at the back of class, donâ€™t know the proper Sanskrit names for the poses, and mostly copy the person in front of me. But thatâ€™s exactly what keeps me engaged with the practice: The blissful, no-pressure, low intensity of it all (especially in January).

For 28-year-old Refinery29 writer Esther Newman, taking up embroidery without the pressure to get better at it has been a big plus for her mental health. â€œI find it really soothing and calming, having something to channel my nervous energy into, especially something thatâ€™s physical and not screen related,â€ she explains. â€œI like having something creative and artistic thatâ€™s all my own and that I donâ€™t have to qualify through its performance or a rating judged by someone else. Itâ€™s just me who gets to say whether something works or needs a different approach.â€Â 

For many others though, the approach to hobbies is more all or nothing. Research from The British Heart Foundation shows that the shelf life of adult hobbies in the U.K. is 16 months, noting that work commitments, busy family lives, and lack of motivation are the main reasons we let them slide. The societal pressure to be instantly great at something is likely a contributing factor in our apathy towards hobbies. How many times have you heard someone saying they want to start running, only for every conversation to become about Fitbits and training for a half marathon? The very idea that you donâ€™t have to be brilliant at everything you do seems to have gotten lost in our never-ending grind culture.

But why canâ€™t our hobbies just beâ€¦ Fun? In a world where weâ€™re constantly on the clock or our iPhones, measuring our successes to our timelines and group chats, shouldnâ€™t hobbies simply be a space for relaxation? According to therapist and Counseling Directory member Rose Fisher, engaging in hobbies on a more chilled basis is not only more enjoyable, but it can also be a major win for our minds. â€œTaking up casual hobbies simply for the joy of it is important for our overall mental health and wellbeing,â€ she tells Refinery29. The benefits of engaging in an activity for no other reason than fun allows us to achieve what she calls a flow state: That is, engrossed and focused on a single task, according to Fisher, which allows us to be fully present and rid ourselves of self-consciousness.

This, she adds, in turn, helps to calm down our â€œthinking mind.â€ â€œThe prefrontal cortex decreases in activity when an individual reaches a state of flow and this reduced activity in the prefrontal cortex enables us to be more creative and also think more freely,â€ Fisher explains.

While it might seem like a strange concept for our overstimulated brains, it is possible to go back to picking up and putting down hobbies when and if we feel like it. Just because we might have invested time into something, it doesnâ€™t mean we have to force ourselves to continue with an enjoyable routine. The idea of having to commit fully to something, reach goals and engage with it â€œproperlyâ€ is exactly what moves us away from the flow state, creating a feeling of unnecessary expectation and guilt if we donâ€™t reach those markers.

Getting back to that source of exploration was something that 27-year-old aerial performer Ruby Baker has experienced since taking up piano last month. â€œI love learning something new for the sake of it. Thereâ€™s no pressure and it allows me to take my mind off all the other things I have to do,â€ she says. â€œIâ€™m a bit of a perfectionist so itâ€™s really good for me to try something Iâ€™m not good at and have a laugh with it. It takes away any self-criticism and judgment and reminds me that thereâ€™s no right or wrong when youâ€™re creating art.â€

One of the main reasons that hobbies began to feel so much like work is due in a large part to the evolution of the side hustle. Bolstered by never-ending COVID lockdowns, and TikTok feeds where everyone seems to be turning their knitting hobby into cold hard cash, for many the opportunity to make money has come at the price of falling out of love with their chosen activity. â€œAdding financial pressures to a passion, or setting high goals for a hobby can have a negative impact on our fulfillment, as it takes away the simplicity of engaging with the task just for the pleasure of it,â€ Fisher explains.

Just because yoga brings me joy by engaging with a hobby in a casual, friends-with-benefits kind of way doesnâ€™t mean I donâ€™t feel the ongoing threat to commit and level up. In a cost of living crisis where extracurriculars are increasingly expensive (my membership is $50 a month), the feeling that activities must be productive to be worth doing has never felt stronger, which is precisely what keeps most of us from taking them up or sticking to them.

For 29-year-old radio presenter Mary Mandefield, this is one of the reasons her recent bouldering hobby has been kept casual. â€œIâ€™m a big believer in not making money from the things you really love. As soon as something turns into a hustle or a career, it can suck the joy from it. I used to be a dance teacher, and as much as I loved making some extra money from dancing around with my mates, I quickly learnt that having to think about insurance, marketing, and GDPR [general data protection regulation] made it less fun,â€ she tells Refinery29.

â€œIt is very important to have some experiences in life that are not about achieving goals, proving ourselves, or winning at things,â€ Fisher explains. â€œThese activities help us to remember that our worth does not depend on what we can do, and we donâ€™t have to prove ourselves to be impressive, valuable, or useful in every aspect of our lives.â€Â 

24-year-old designer Georgina*, who previously went out running every day, recognizes her relationship with the activity is much better now that itâ€™s more relaxed. â€œIt used to feel like a chore and I believed that if I missed a run then everything would be ruined. Not only my progressâ€¦ It was more like: okay, that was a wasted day because I didnâ€™t run my five miles,â€ she says. â€œNow, I donâ€™t want to run because I â€˜plannedâ€™ it, but just do it when I feel I need it. I actually enjoy it without the demand of getting better and I really donâ€™t want to spoil that magic. Itâ€™s so comforting to do something just for yourself without any kind of pressure, whether that be internal or external.â€

While it might take some mental reframing to break free of our overachieving mindsets, seeing hobbies as less of a routine-orientated practice and more as a source of play is a start. According to therapist and Counseling Directory member Rosalind Miles, the social aspect is also incredibly important. â€œHobbies often bring people together who share similar interests,â€ she says. â€œJoining clubs or participating in group activities related to your hobby can foster a sense of community and provide opportunities for people to get out and about and make new friends.â€

As January brings with it unending conversations about what we want to â€œachieveâ€ this year, giving ourselves permission to engage with activities we like on a â€œwhen we feel like itâ€ basis seems like one way to actually keep going with them. The inherent shame of being average at something is stopping us from engaging with anything â€”Â when really we all know that doing a little bit of something that we find fun is better than avoiding it entirely for fear of not being able to achieve anything of significance. Stepping out every so often to take part in something is a win in itself and itâ€™s time we were all reminded of it.Â 

My next venture for the new year? Roller skating. Hereâ€™s hoping for more laughs than broken bones.

*Names have been changed.

This article was originally published in January 2024 and has since been updated.

title: 6 Netflix Treats You Should Watch In January
text:
6 Netflix Treats You Should Watch In January

Itâ€™s a brand new year, and that means plenty of new content to binge! If the holiday season tired you out, feel free to start 2026 from your couch. For those of you looking for some boredom busters before you make the dreaded return to work, there are plenty of films and TV shows coming to our screens in January. From much-anticipated book-to-screen adaptations to popular TV shows, thereâ€™s bound to be something that suits.

Whether you prefer to join Yerin Ha in the Ton or solve mysteries involving Helena Bonham Carter, Netflix is the place to be in January. Plus, you donâ€™t even have to leave the comfort of your own home, which is much-needed after a whirlwind Christmas season. To take a look at the best titles coming to Netflix this January, read on.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Stranger Things 5: The Finale

Stranger Things 5 concludes with a 125-minute series finale, releasing at 12 pm AEDT. If youâ€™re nursing a hangover from your big NYE celebration, why not grab some greasy fries and delve into the world of Hawkins?

When:Â January 1
Watch if you like:Â IT, Midnight Mass

DashDividers_1_500x100

His & Hers

Tessa Thompson and Jon Bernthal play estranged spouses in this mystery thriller series based on Alice Feeneyâ€™s popular novel. After a murder takes place in a small village, the two are thrust back into close proximity again. With journalist Anna and cop Jack competing to solve a murder, the estranged spouses begin to suspect each other.

When:Â January 8
Watch if you like:Â Locked In, Gone Girl

DashDividers_1_500x100

People We Meet On Vacation

Based on the novel by Emily Henry, this romantic comedy follows Emily Bader as Poppy and Tom Blyth as Alex. The estranged friends find themselves on one last trip together, and sparks fly. This film also stars Sarah Catherine Hook, Jameela Jamil, Lucien Laviscount, Lukas Gage, Alice Lee and Molly Shannon.

When:Â January 8
Watch if you like: Friendzone, Love in the Villa

DashDividers_1_500x100

Agatha Christieâ€™s Seven Dials

After a murder takes place during a lavish country house party, a plucky young aristocrat is determined to solve the crime in this gripping TV series. Starring Mia McKenna-Bruce, Helena Bonham Carter, Martin Freeman and Corey Mylchreest, this period drama promises great twists and heightened suspense.

When:Â January 15
Watch if you like: Knives Out, Bodies

DashDividers_1_500x100

Love Through A Prism

Famous manga author Yoko Kamio is back with Love Through A Prism, an animated series about a young woman who attends art school to become a painter. After her rivalry with a classmate turns into romance, this TV show illustrates how quickly love can develop.

Directed by Kazuto Nakazawa (anime director of Kill Bill: Volume 1), the coming-of-age story appears both touching and beautiful.

When:Â January 15
Watch if you like: Violet Evergarden, A Whisker Away

DashDividers_1_500x100

Bridgerton: Season 4 Part 1

Bridgerton Season 4Â focuses on the second son, Benedict (Luke Thompson). The bachelor isnâ€™t fussed about settling down until he crosses paths with Sophie Baek (Yerin Ha) during a masquerade ball.

The series also welcomes newcomers Katie Leung, Michelle Mao and Isabella Wei, as well as returning stars Claudia Jessie, Nicola Coughlan, Ruth Gemmell, Florence Hunt, Polly Walker, Adjoa Andoh, Luke Newton, Golda Rosheuvel, Simone Ashley and more.

When:Â January 29
Watch if you like: Queen Charlotte, One Day

title: 21 Matching Lounge Sets & Sweatsuits To Cozy Up In For Winter
text:
21 Matching Lounge Sets & Sweatsuits To Cozy Up In For Winter As much as we love diving headfirst into the latest fashion trends, thereâ€™s no denying the magnetic pull of a matching set â€” from sweatsuits to loungewear â€” especially during the winter.Â Theyâ€™re cozy, comfy, cute â€” and, when made with quality and care, built to last. Plus, theyâ€™re versatile! Toeing the line between sporty athleisure and polished co-ords, sweatsuits are the ultimate shortcut to looking casual yet put-together.Â 

Throw one on when you can't be bothered to style an outfit for running errands, going to workout classes, or attending a football game. Working remotely and need to feel slightly more â€œdressedâ€ than your pajamas? Problem solved. And on travel days? Sweat sets are an MVP for curling up on chilly flights. (Bonus: You can break up a set and wear each piece separately, unlocking endless mix-and-match potential for those moments when you actually want to plan an outfit.)

If youâ€™re ready to retire those ratty, hole-y sweats that have seen you through college and countless days under your duvet (no judgment â€” weâ€™ve all got that pair), consider yourself covered. Ahead, discover 21 cotton sets, waffle knit co-ords, and fleece layers for indoor hibernation mode and outdoorsy winter activities from retailers we love and trust, like Lululemon and Free People.

All linked products are independently selected by our editors. If you purchase any of these products, we may earn a commission.

title: Blue Suede Is The Nail Color Combo Everyone Wants This Year, Say Manicurists
text:
Blue Suede Is The Nail Color Combo Everyone Wants This Year, Say Manicurists

One of my favorite things about this job is getting to hunt forÂ manicure inspirationÂ andÂ callÂ it work. In the past few weeks,Â Iâ€™veÂ spotted (and promptly booked)Â cat-eye polka-dot nails,Â not to mentionÂ argyle sweater nails, and evenÂ deer-print nailsÂ â€” a cute winterÂ alternativeÂ to tortoiseshell. But asÂ Iâ€™veÂ been tracking the coolest trends, oneÂ color combination keeps coming up. Enter:Â blue and brown.Â Actually,Â Iâ€™mÂ calling itÂ blueÂ suede.Â 

I know whatÂ youâ€™reÂ thinking:Â itâ€™sÂ not the most obviousÂ color pairing, and on paper, itÂ shouldnâ€™tÂ work. But judging by Instagramâ€™s nail artists, the duo is surprisingly dynamic,Â andÂ itâ€™sÂ quickly becoming one of their most requested designs.Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by MANCHESTER BIAB & NAIL ART SPECIALIST ğŸ¤ ZOE GRIFFITHS (@griffsgelstudio)

BIABÂ and nail art specialistÂ Zoe GriffithsÂ saysÂ that blue and brown isÂ her clientsâ€™Â favorite color combinationÂ at the minute,Â andÂ thereâ€™sÂ a simpleÂ reasonÂ whyÂ the twoÂ hues go togetherÂ so perfectly:Â â€œBlue and brown isÂ natureâ€™sÂ color palette,â€ saysÂ GriffithsÂ â€” think of it like the earth meeting the sky.Â Griffiths adds,Â â€œTogether, theyâ€™reÂ warm and cool at the same time,Â soÂ this combination suitsÂ everyone.â€Â Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by N O I R B E A U T Y (@noir.beauty____)

In the same way that theÂ argyle patternÂ has transcended fashion and made its way onto our nails, Griffiths thinks that our obsession withÂ these shadesÂ comes from a small tweak weâ€™re making to ourÂ closets: â€œIÂ think recentlyÂ a lot of people have been replacing black with chocolate brown as a softer wardrobe staple,â€ she says, adding, â€œBrown and blue as a nail combo will be trending asÂ itâ€™sÂ a fun way to wearÂ color, butÂ itÂ still somehow feels likeÂ youâ€™reÂ wearing neutrals as theyÂ match so easily toÂ the clothes that most of usÂ already have inÂ ourÂ wardrobes.â€Â Itâ€™sÂ further proof that blue denim really does go with everything.Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by HEATHER ERRINGTON (@nailsbyheather.errington)

If you want to switch things up, some manicurists are replacing brown tones with rich burgundy, and whileÂ seeming like an unusual match, the various creations posted to Instagram prove otherwise. We especially love this blue andÂ burgundy combinationÂ byÂ nail salon Faness, which marries a wine-colored baseÂ andÂ sky blueÂ daubs.Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Faness (@fanessdetroit)

IfÂ youâ€™reÂ doing your nails at home,Â Essieâ€™sÂ Nail Art Studio Jelly Gloss Nail Polish in Sky JellyÂ is a soft baby blue hue that suits all skin tones. Layer it withÂ a rich chestnut shade likeÂ Manucurist Green Nail Polish in Mocha, orÂ OPI Nail Lacquer in You Donâ€™t Know Jacques!Â if you prefer something lighter.Â Â 

For intricate nail designs involving gel,Â itâ€™sÂ best head to a qualified nail artist. Ahead, find all the inspiration you needÂ to wear the coolestÂ color combination of the season.Â Â 

Blue Coffee Plaid

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by kiri. wnia-ãƒ‹ã‚¢- (@kiri_wnia)

Plaid print nailsÂ arenâ€™tÂ going anywhere, but the 2026 upgrade is keeping things monochrome. Nail artistÂ kiri. wniaÂ has taken inspiration from Pantoneâ€™s Chicory Coffee (aÂ smoky brown) and Blue Bell (a powdery pastel blue)Â and delicately layered them to create thisÂ blueÂ and brown set that appearsÂ almost jelly-like.Â Â 

Queen of Hearts

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by HEATHER ERRINGTON (@nailsbyheather.errington)

ManicuristÂ Heather ErringtonÂ called thisÂ color combo last summer, butÂ itâ€™sÂ just as popular this winter. Her design starts with a rich chocolate base, topped with hand-painted baby blue hearts that accentuate the nail tips.Â 

Geometric Shapes

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Brittney Ellen (@brushedbyb_)

Brittney Ellen is the genius behind this dark chocolate and bright blue geometric manicure. We love how the negative space between the blue shapesÂ allowsÂ the rich base to peek through.Â Â 

OmbrÃ© Tips

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by NAILZ (@nailz.mty)

Nail artist @nailz.mtyÂ has topped this deep espresso shade withÂ light blue to create anÂ ombrÃ¨Â French tip effect. We love the neatÂ squovalÂ shapeÂ ofÂ these natural nails,Â but this would look equally chic on longer almond nails.Â Â 

Blue Horizon

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by HEATHER ERRINGTON (@nailsbyheather.errington)

Another winner fromÂ Heather Errington, this set champions a caramelized brown shade, butÂ weÂ alsoÂ adoreÂ the delicate sliverÂ of blueÂ over the center of the nail, whichÂ looks likeÂ a sky on the horizon.Â Â 

Monochrome Polka Dots

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Suelen Bagley | Nail TechğŸ¦‹ (@nailsbysue__)

Nail techÂ SuelenÂ Bagley shows that thisÂ color combo can be fun with a mix of French tips,Â polka dots, andÂ dot-adorned starsÂ on a blockÂ color and neutral base. The stiletto shape is the cherry on top.Â Â 

Studded Aura

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by San Sung Kim | á„€á…µá†·á„‰á…¡á†«á„‰á…¥á†¼ (@sansungnails)

On the topic of aura nails,Â San Sung KimÂ flipped the shades, layering a powder blue base under a veil of brown polish, accented with studs.Â 

Inverted Florals

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Megan â­‘ Free Hand Natural Nail Artist â­‘ North East (@shybairnstudios)

Freehand naturalÂ nail artist MeganÂ dreamed up these baby blue and chocolate chubby flowers, inverting theÂ colors on each hand.Â 

Blueberry Jelly

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Sierra â€“ Nail Polish | Nail Art (@thatglosssauce)

Thereâ€™sÂ something deliciously dessert-like about these nails by Sierra. UsingÂ Butter London Patent Shine Nail Lacquer inÂ Afters, she painted chocolate brown swirls over a blueberry jelly base (Dimension Nails Blueberry Flax Milk) to create this playful look.Â 

Blue-Meets-Burgundy

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğ¦ğšğ«ğ² ğ‚‚â€¦ (@_nailbymary)

If coffee tonesÂ arenâ€™tÂ your thing, opt for something warmer and richer, like this brooding oxblood.Â Nail artist MaryÂ created a blown-out aura effect, adding studs to some nails and chrome marbling to others.Â 

Blue Tortie Tips

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nikkiâ€™s Nails (@nails.by.nikk)

At first glance, these nails created by Nikki seem simple, but the French tips are decked out in tortoiseshell print. The blue swipe cupping each tip adds the perfect finishing touch. We also love her blue and brown snake print tips.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nikkiâ€™s Nails (@nails.by.nikk)

title: I Found Keeping A Journal Hard Until I Used These Prompts
text:
I Found Keeping A Journal Hard Until I Used These Prompts

Iâ€™ve never been the sort of person who keeps a diary. There was that fluffy padlocked notebook in my tweens, but I only ever occasionally remembered its existence. If I could find it now in the ruins and cardboard boxes of my childhood, it would likely be 85% blank pages, 10% doodles, and 5% â€œspy notesâ€ about my family (nothing quite like scribbling down all of your loved onesâ€™ movements, eh?).

Still, like countless others, Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time watching influencersâ€™ morning and evening routines on social media. A lot of time. And, yes, Iâ€™ve noticed that almost all of them include a journaling session or two. It makes a lot of sense: Studies have repeatedly shown that engaging in regular journaling can help reduce stress, manage anxiety and depression symptoms, enhance self-awareness, promote emotional regulation, provide opportunities for positive self-talk, and even strengthen resilience in the face of challenges. If you can stick to it.Â 

Intrigued by all of the above, and keen to see if it could help me get a better handle on my own stresses and worries, I decided to give it a go for myself â€” but not before consulting with the experts. And, as youâ€™ve likely guessed already, it turns out my snarky tween diary definitely wouldnâ€™t cut it when it comes to reaping the myriad psychological benefits of this popular pastime.Â 

â€œJournaling is essentially another way of saying â€˜putting our thoughts and feelings down on paper,â€™ giving them a place to exist outside of our heads,â€ explains mental health advocate, author of Therapy Isâ€¦Magic, and trainee psychotherapist Jo Love, describing it as a â€œtool that allows us to process our emotions and creates an opportunity for self-reflection.â€

â€œIts effectiveness varies based on individual preferences and psychological needs,â€ adds author, psychologist and certified therapist, Kalanit Ben-Ari, PhD. â€œReflective journaling is particularly beneficial for emotional release, processing feelings and thoughts, and reducing anxiety. It enhances self-awareness; as one writes, reads, and perhaps edits or adds to their entries, they create a psychological space between themselves and their thoughts and feelings. This process allows for framing experiences and opens the door for processing and reframing.â€

Reassuring me that there are no set rules for how to journal â€œproperly,â€ Love notesÂ that â€œthere are thousands of helpful ideas and prompts out there if you find yourself staring fruitlessly at a blank page.â€Â 

â€œThe main thing is to ditch the guilt about achieving perfection,â€ she adds. â€œEven if all you do is write a single line, then that is totally OK.â€

â€œPersonal preference absolutely plays a role,â€ agreesÂ Dr. Ben-Ari. â€œSome find it beneficial to write in the morning to set intentions and establish a positive mindset for the day, while others prefer journaling before bed, which helps in reflecting on the day and calming the mind for a good nightâ€™s sleep.â€

With their advice in mind, I dug an unused notebook out from the back of a drawer, scoured the house for a pen (a fruitless task: I wound up buying a pack of biros at the corner shop), and positioned them artfully beside my bed.

Reader, I wonâ€™t lie to you: I found it incredibly difficult to think of anything to write for the first few nights and mornings. The words of my universityâ€™s creative writing tutor rang in my ears, however â€” just start writing, and the words will come â€” and so thatâ€™s what I did. I wrote banal little sentences about my day: about what Iâ€™d eaten for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. About how delayed the trains had been. About the weather (how incredibly, painfully British of me). Unsurprisingly, I began to view the journaling as a chore to be ticked off, rather than as valuable time for myself.Â 

This is normal: as humans, we are notoriously bad at forging new habits. In fact, research shows that 23% of people quit their resolutions by the end of the first week, and 43% quit by the end of January. â€œLike resolutions, you might start journaling with great intentions and goodwill, but find they often fade within a few weeks,â€ says Dr. Ben-Ari.Â â€œPeople might find it hard to stick to a journaling schedule, as it doesnâ€™t offer the same benefits for everyoneâ€™s mental and emotional health.â€

Thankfully, both of my experts had some tips on how to get more out of my tentative journaling experiment â€” in the hope that I might be able to keep the good habit in place for longer.

â€œTreat your journal as a private exploration space just for you and no one else,â€ suggests Love. â€œTake some time to reflect on your day, important events in your life, or decisions youâ€™ve made. You might want to jot down anything youâ€™re worried or bothered about. It can be helpful, too, to think about what has made you feel good or proud of yourself. And a letter to your past or future self can be a truly powerful experience.â€

Dr. Ben-Ari, meanwhile, had another suggestion with regards to what to write. â€œIn my clinic, I encourage clients to keep a dream journal, as dreams, which are easily forgotten, carry messages from our inner wisdom and unconscious,â€ she told me. â€œWriting them down serves three functions: remembering the dreams; learning about the dreams narratives and themes; and noticing the psychological shifts they reflect in therapy.â€

I began taking a cup of chamomile tea up with me to bed and sipping it as I noted down all of my thoughts and feelings in a bid to make my head â€” and world â€” feel that little bit clearer. Iâ€™m the sort of socially anxious person who worries over every perceived slight, so I used my journal to explore these fears rather than lying awake obsessing over them. And, as someone whose inner critic is her biggest bully, it was genuinely lovely to take a moment each night to pay attention to the things Iâ€™d done well â€” no matter how small.Â 

As time ticked on, I found myself looking forward to curling up in bed with my journal. And, as someone who usually spends a great deal of time tossing and turning and fretting before eventually plunging headfirst into a series of anxiety-fueled dreams (dreams which Iâ€™m now making a point of committing to paper, I hasten to add), Iâ€™m happy to report that I found myself falling asleep more quickly after journaling, too. The dreams have proven as erratic as ever, mind you, but Iâ€™m hoping that keeping this habit up will help to improve them over time.

If Iâ€™m being completely honest, my inner cynic wanted this experiment to prove a failure. Iâ€™ve never been fond of elaborate morning and evening routines â€” especially when they reek of â€œwellbeing washingâ€ â€” and all of the â€œclick to buyâ€ links on peopleâ€™s social media made me assume it was nothing but a cash grab.Â 

I also found that buying myself an extra-special sparkly notebook added a sense of occasion to proceedings, but anything will do the job in a pinch. All you really need is a few minutes each day: Yes, many people aim to write for 15 or 20 minutes, but starting small is honestly the best way to set a habit in motion (and, if youâ€™re anything like me, youâ€™ll find that you wind up writing more and more as the weeks tick by).

If you need some help getting started, Love suggests that you try something like â€œa â€˜gratitude journalâ€™ and jot down three things youâ€™re grateful for, or a â€˜one sentence a dayâ€™ approach to help take the pressure off, particularly for those who find writing hard or are out of practice. â€œWriting about whatever events, thoughts or feelings that came up that day can be another simple entry point to journaling,â€ she adds.

Just one word of caution: While this activity has proven incredibly beneficial to many people, and while I myself have been won over, itâ€™s important to pay attention to how the activity makes you feel. Everyone is different.

â€œReflective journaling, when feeling overwhelmed, offers a space to make sense of experiences and feelings, helping to calm the mind,â€ says Dr. Ben-Ari. â€œHowever, I generally donâ€™t recommend journaling â€˜to-do listsâ€™ as they can add stress or distract from deeper issues that need attention. Also, writing that dwells excessively on negative events or feelings, a process known as over-rumination, can lead to increased stress. Concerns about privacy can also impact the honesty needed for reflective journaling.â€

Adding that â€œitâ€™s also important to note that not everyone enjoys writing,â€ Ben-Ari notes that its benefits can still be reaped â€œthrough art, drawing or other creative means as a way to process feelings.â€ We just need to remember that it is a tool, and use it in a way that works best for us as individuals.

On that note, Iâ€™m off to bed â€” and, yes, youâ€™d best believe Iâ€™ll be journaling about the experience of writing about journaling. Things are about to get incredibly metaâ€¦

This article was originally published in January 2024 and has since been updated.

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

14 Best Journals For Getting Your Thoughts Out

This Journal-Planner Hybrid Is My Best-Self Secret

This Wellness Journal Relaxed My Mind

title: Sophie Turner & Archie Madekwe On The â€œDangersâ€ Of Excessive Wealth Hoarding By Billionaires
text:
Sophie Turner & Archie Madekwe On The â€œDangersâ€ Of Excessive Wealth Hoarding By Billionaires

Sophie Turner and Archie Madekweâ€™s newest Prime Video show Steal centers around a major heist where billions of pounds are stolen from a London pension fund. Without giving any spoilers (thereâ€™s a lot of twists revealed throughout the show), the series broadly focuses on how much wealth in society is controlled by a small percentage of people, how it affects all of us workers in the capitalist regime, and what lengths people will go to for money.

Turner plays Zara, your regular office worker who barely earns a living wage while working at a swanky office in Londonâ€™s wealthy financial district. The show depicts the fallout after thieves hold the office workers hostage and steal billions of pounds from peopleâ€™s pensions. As Zara and her friend Luke (Madekwe) try to solve the mystery, things get complicated, and lives are at stake.

Madekwe tells Refinery29 itâ€™s â€œvery dangerousâ€ to have so much wealth controlled by so few people, which he believes Steal conveys well. â€œItâ€™s incredibly prevalent right nowâ€¦ I think the show kind of explores that in a lot of ways, but of course, itâ€™s awful,â€ the actor says. â€œI think people can relate to [the show]. I think everybody is feeling [stuck], you know? And everybody feels helpless, and there are people [who] could change the situation, and donâ€™tâ€¦ the disparity [in wealth] is huge, and it isnâ€™t fair. And yeah, itâ€™s anarchic.â€

Turner adds that Steal shows how desperation, when it comes to money, can push people to the limit. â€œWeâ€™ve got too many billionaires and the cost-of-living crisis [means] the disparity is too big, and the gapâ€™s got to close. I wish I could do something about it, but I just canâ€™t,â€ she says. â€œBut thatâ€™s what I like about the show, as well. It explores why good people do bad things, and it is for reasons like this. So thatâ€™s what I love, exploring that.â€

For Turner, sheâ€™s previously played fantasy characters like Sansa Stark (Game of Thrones), Jean Grey (X-Men: Apocalpyse) and more recently, 1980s character Joan (Joan). Itâ€™s no surprise that for a show tackling topics like wealth inequality, her role as Zara in Steal hits closer to home, with family trauma, a messy love life, and other relatable traits. But rather than missing an extravagant wardrobe or hours in makeup, she relished the chance to tell a story in a different way. â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever played a character quite as messy as her and it was really fun because I felt like I could just show up.. itâ€™s just very relieving when you donâ€™t have to wear a corset and your shoulders arenâ€™t pulled back, you donâ€™t have to talk in a certain way,â€ Turner says. â€œI could just kind of flop about, I donâ€™t know how else to explain it. I felt so free in playing her, I think thatâ€™s what I mean,â€ she adds. â€œ[Sheâ€™s the] closest to me as any character Iâ€™ve played.â€

While her character Zara is more ordinary than most others sheâ€™s stepped into, being held at gunpoint is anything but. While youâ€™d imagine being put through your paces by masked thieves would be taxing, Turner actually just saw that action-packed day as another day in the officeâ€¦ literally. â€œI really thrive on days when it is a high-stakes day where itâ€™s a lot of drama and a lot of emotion, and I actually find it quite cathartic,â€ the actor says. â€œI go home feeling much better about myself than I did walking in. I think thatâ€™s what acting is for me, is therapy. I always feel better going home and itâ€™s easy to step out of it.â€

And even though the actors might not take home the anxiety or emotions from set, Stealâ€™s fast-paced show could very well induce it in viewers. But Madekwe notes thatâ€™s the reason viewers watch heist shows in the first place. â€œItâ€™s like fun, escapism,â€ he explains. â€œI always love [watching] things that make me kind of physically feel something. And if something gets your heart racing, kind of builds anxiety in that way like a show like this does, and youâ€™re able to create that in your own home, then I think itâ€™s so exciting. And this show, I think, really succeeds with that.â€

All six episodes of Steal will be able to stream on Amazon Prime Video on January 21, 2026.

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

Meet 'Identity Capital': Is It A Self-Help Scam?

What Women Have Given Up Due To Cost Of Living

When Your Mental Health Costs You Your Job

title: The Best Red Carpet Looks At The 2026 Critics Choice Awards
text:
The Best Red Carpet Looks At The 2026 Critics Choice Awards Awards season has kicked off with the 2026 Critics Choice Awards, and multiple stars nabbed shiny trophies. Sarah Snook won Best Actress in a Limited Series for All Her Fault, the Sinners cast won Best Casting Ensemble, and Jacob Elordi took home a statue for Best Supporting Actor in Frankenstein. But there's one part of the awards show that's much more subjective â€” the outfits the celebrities show up in.

There were some major wins on the red carpet, with Mia Goth stepping out in Dior and Ariana Grande channelling her inner-Glinda in a beaded Alberta Ferretti number. We've rounded up the best looks from the Critics Awards 2026 carpet, from classic Hollywood old glamour to more daring dresses.

title: These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists
text:
These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists

From the bob to the bixie, short haircuts have become the style of choice in salons up and down the country. Though they all look incredible, theyâ€™re also pretty high maintenance.Â 

For those who donâ€™t like the idea of booking in for a monthly trim, a midi, shoulder-length cut might be your best bet. Far from mediocre, the in-between length isnâ€™t only much easier to keep sharp â€” itâ€™s also being touted as one of the biggest hair trends for 2026. â€œMid-length cuts donâ€™t have to feel like a long, grown-out bob,â€ says Jordan Jones, stylist and color technician at Taylor Taylor London. â€œThis year, weâ€™re being shown that they can be their own style with layers and careful shaping to create volume and movement, or shine and sophistication. If your bob has grown out and your hair has reached that awkward-length stage, or if youâ€™ve got long locks and fancy a change without going super short, a trendy mid-length style is the cut for you.â€

On Instagram, Londonâ€™s most sought-after stylists The Hair Bros are also championing shoulder-length haircuts with curtain bangs, concave layers, and natural waves. It seems weâ€™ve all got the same idea: Google search for shoulder-length haircuts has risen by 180% recently.

So which shoulder-length haircut will suit you best? Ahead, stylists reveal the biggest shoulder-length haircut trends that everyone can wear.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Shoulder-Length Drape

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nicolas Flores (@nicolasfloreshair)

Curtain bangs are going nowhere fast, but according to editorial hairstylist and presenter Neil Moodie, you might want to cancel your fringe trim, because itâ€™s increasingly cool to let it grow out a little. â€œGrown-out curtain fringes are great and can make shoulder-length hair look more interesting,â€ he says. The more grown out the fringe, the easier it is to blend into the rest of your hair, particularly if youâ€™re interested in getting a handful of layers to enhance volume and texture, like this style by hairstylist
Nicolas Flores.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Jagged Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Callan de Villiers (@callandevilliers)

â€œAs the bob and long bobs have been around for a while, I feel like fringes are making a comeback,â€ says Moodie. â€œThe type of fringe I mean almost looks a bit homemade and very individual. Itâ€™s slightly jagged on the ends and a little uneven.â€ Take a cue from this choppy cut on Callan de Villiers by Cort Bray.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Mane

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Francesca Inverarity (@frankie_inv)

Youâ€™ve heard of the wolf cut (a variation on the shag, occupying a space between wild and relaxed) but â€˜the maneâ€™ is a lot more voluminous. â€œThis is super edgy with lots of texture and a heavy fringe that needs to be worn long and in the eyes so it has plenty of movement,â€ explains Jordan Jones, stylist and color technician at Taylor Taylor London. â€œThe face-framing layers of this cut make it perfect for adding texture and volume to the hair while defining the face.â€

So what should you ask for? â€œA choppy cut with plenty of layers that frame the face and create soft movement,â€ says Jones. â€œThink Billie Eilish and Miley Cyrusâ€™s shaggy â€˜dos.â€ Jones says the look works well with any hair texture. â€œSea salt products are a must-have to give an effortless, freshly tousled finishing touch.â€ Take inspiration from this look by Francesca Inverarity.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Shoulder-Length Afro

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Diliana van Rijn (@diliana.nvr)

â€œAs we move into spring and summer, I think weâ€™ll be seeing a lot more natural afro and curly hair in medium lengths,â€ says celebrity hairdresser Lorraine Dublin, much like this beautiful, fluffed-out afro on Diliana van Rijn. â€œIn the colder months, hair thrives better in protective styles, so as the weather heats up, weâ€™ll be seeing afro hair in its natural state â€” with bold colors, too.â€

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Half Up, Half Down

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by dylan bradshaw DUBLIN (@dylanbradshawdublin)

â€œAnother trend that will continue to be popular is the half-up, half-down style,â€ says Lorraine, â€œespecially with hair extensions.â€ She continues: â€œYou can add an ombre hair color to the ends and combine this with a natural, soft, body wave.â€ Gemma Murphy from Dylan Bradshaw, Dublin,Â totally nails the cute in-between style here.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Collarbone Cut

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Jessenia Robayo (@jesseniaspallet)

â€œThe collarbone cut is so popular right now,â€ says Tyler Moore, stylist at Live True London. He prefers a blunt edge and no layering, but the look works equally well with a little bit of texture. â€œThis style can be paired with a fringe for an ultra chic look, and it works great on both straight and wavy or textured hair.â€ We love this look on Jessenia Robayo.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Flip

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alexia Colombo (@iamalexiaclb)

The Hair Bros say a shoulder-length cut is its own style and that itâ€™s important not to leave all of the hair one length. â€œThis will end up looking heavy, as if it were a shorter bob. A middy haircut should be full of texture and life and feel fun and playful. Itâ€™s great for anyone who wants to cut their long hair short but isnâ€™t quite ready to brave a bob.â€ Flip your hair to one side for more of a natural, lived-in feel, like this cut on Alexia Colombo. â€œAs always, just a few products and some air should be enough to style this cut,â€ added The Hair Bros.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The â€™90s Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by The Labartory (@the.labartory)

The â€™90s lob (aka long bob) is going to be everywhere again this year, says Tyler. â€œThis is a layered, mid-length long bob Ã  la Rachel from Friends. Think of it as a more retro twist on the wolf cut with slightly longer layers and a sleeker texture.â€ Dreamed up by @the.labartory on Instagram, this lob is both glossy and textured.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Hi-Shine Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Emiliano Breit (@emilianobreitsalon)

â€œEmbrace modern glamour with a super blunt cut with clean, sharp lines,â€ says Jones, like this cut created by Emiliano Breit. â€œThis style looks best when cut around the collarbone and is perfectly set off with mirror-shine hair.â€ This is all about the condition of your hair, so make sure to use hydrating and nourishing conditioners or oils to create a super sleek style. KÃ©rastase Elixir Ultime Lâ€™Original Hair Oil, is a favorite among stylists.

â€œIf you are a brunette or darker, ask for a gloss color to add depth and shine,â€ adds Jones. â€œEven opting for a Brazilian blow-dry or straightening treatment will help to put the finishing touches on this look.â€

DashDividers_1_500x100

Lived-In Lengths

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğ‘…ğ“Šğ’·ğ“ ğ’¯ğ“Šğ‘’ğ“ˆğ’¹ğ’¶ğ“ ğ¸ğ“‹ğ‘’ğ“‡ğ“ˆ (@didntcatchthat)

â€œWhy is shoulder-length hair commonly perceived to be bad?â€ wrote The Hair Bros on Instagram. â€œItâ€™s not!â€ This modern shoulder-length cut by hairstylist Liam Russell on Ruby Tuesday Evers has inspired the Brosâ€™ work in-salon over the past few months. The bedhead texture and mussed-up fringe give the medium length great shape.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Top-Heavy Cut

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğ•°ğ–’ğ–ğ–‘ğ– ğ•¶ğ–ğ–“ğ–Œğ–˜ğ–™ğ–”ğ–“ (@lemzkingston)

The shag, the mullet, the shulletâ€¦ Whatever you call the â€˜00s most popular cut, it always seems to be evolving, as illustrated by Emily Kingston, stylist and colorist at Blue Tit Clapton. Proving the cut looks just as incredible on curly hair, the trick is to emphasize lots of volume around the top of the head and taper the lengths right down to the bottom so that hair sits just below the collarbone.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Flipped Side Bangs

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by â‹† Billie Brown â‹† (@billiebrown)

The flipped side bang perfectly accentuates a shoulder-length cut, says Jones, like this style on Billie Brown. â€œCurtain bangs have moved on, and side bangs from the early â€™00s are back. For fringe lovers who want a bit more excitement this year, this style flatters most face shapes and essentially frames the face with disconnected, slightly longer bangs. Itâ€™s not dramatic and easy to tuck behind your ear, pin to one side, or sweep across the forehead with a big, bouncy blow-dry.â€

Jones says it looks great on wavy, thicker hair in particular, styled as if itâ€™s been casually flipped over. â€œTo keep it on trend, itâ€™s best worn loose and tousled. Add spritzes of dry shampoo on the roots for second-day hair to amplify the volume and add a bit of texture.â€

Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?

Bobs & Bangs: 17 Revamped Haircut Trends For 2026

12 Bob Haircuts Youâ€™ll See Everywhere In 2026

I Got The J-Shape Haircut & Found My Forever Style

title: I Dropped Prescription Skincare When I Found This $15 Retinal Serum
text:
I Dropped Prescription Skincare When I Found This $15 Retinal Serum

Until a few weeks ago, I was faithfully using aÂ prescription retinoidÂ recommended by a trusted dermatologist â€” and my skin had never looked worse. My first mistake was assuming that, havingÂ used retinol before, IÂ wouldnâ€™tÂ experience the harsh side effects of a stronger formula. But when my skinÂ wouldnâ€™tÂ stop peeling, my breakouts got worse, and I wasÂ almost outÂ of the tube, I knew something was off.Â SoÂ when TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s newÂ Advanced 0.2% RetinalÂ landed on my desk, promising aÂ fast yet gentleÂ experience for retinoidÂ users, I knew I had toÂ give it a try.Â 

WhatÂ isÂ TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s Advanced 0.2% Retinal, and what are the benefits?Â 

Without getting all lab-coat on youÂ (and before I get into the nitty gritty),Â it helps to know theÂ difference between retinalÂ â€” the star ingredient in TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s new serum â€” and retinol. Both are members of the retinoid family, but they work a little differently.Â Â 

EstheticianÂ Alicia LarteyÂ previously explained to R29 that when retinol is applied to the skin, itÂ goes through several stepsÂ before being converted into retinoic acid, which triggers all the amazing skin benefits, like improvingÂ texture and tone, minimizing fine linesÂ by boosting collagen production, and reducing breakoutsÂ by renewing skin cells.Â Retinal, on the other hand, requires fewer steps to become retinoic acid, so it works faster â€” 11 times faster, according to TheÂ InkeyÂ List.Â Itâ€™sÂ the retinal that gives this serum its striking yellow color, butÂ donâ€™tÂ worry â€” itÂ hasnâ€™tÂ gone bad, and thoughÂ itâ€™sÂ a little reminiscent ofÂ aÂ turmericÂ face mask, itÂ absorbs instantly andÂ wonâ€™tÂ stain your skin. I can vouch for that.Â Â 

The Inkey List Advanced 0.2% Retinal Serum, $15

What makes TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s Advanced 0.2 Retinal special?Â 

Even better,Â TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s retinalÂ is encapsulated, meaningÂ itâ€™sÂ wrapped in tiny moisturizing molecules that release it gradually into the skin. This way, you get all the benefits of a high-powered ingredient with far less irritation â€” no soreness or painfully dry, flaky patchesÂ here.Â Â 

Just whenÂ IÂ thought this productÂ couldnâ€™tÂ get any smarter, it also features 1%Â symsitive, a soothing ingredient that supports the skin barrier (the outer layer that keeps moisture in and bacteria out).Â This is a relief, as retinoids can easily damage the skin barrier if used incorrectly or too often.Â Plus,Â thereâ€™sÂ 2%Â sirtalice, an algae-derived ingredient that helps firm the skin in minutes, making it appear juicy and plump.Â Â 

DashDividers_1_500x100

What to know about TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s 0.2% Advanced Retinal serum

â€” Features 0.2% encapsulated retinal, a high-strength ingredient that works faster than retinol with minimal irritation.Â 

â€” Targets dark spots, rough skin texture, fine lines, and breakouts.Â 

â€” Designed for evening use: two to three times a week at first.Â 

DashDividers_1_500x100

How do you use TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s Advanced 0.2 Retinal, and is it worth it?Â Â 

Iâ€™veÂ been usingÂ Advanced 0.2% RetinalÂ for a few weeks now (a pea-sized amountÂ three nights a week, right after cleansing and before a simple moisturizer), and my skin is already much happier.Â Itâ€™sÂ clearer, bouncier, smoother in texture, and more even in tone, thanks to the retinal helping minimize the red marks left behind by breakouts.Â Here, Iâ€™m wearing a light touch of concealer and blush, and can comfortably skip foundation.

With my skin feeling less dry, the fine lines under my eyes and across my forehead have eased up, too.Â I even bring it down my neck to help zap the occasional hormonal zit. My neck is the first place to feel sensitive when I use retinoids because the skin is thinner here, but so far,Â Iâ€™veÂ not experienced any irritation.Â 

Itâ€™s a lightweight serum, so youâ€™ll want to make sure the moisturizer you applyÂ on topÂ in the eveningÂ is fairly simple and doesnâ€™t contain high-strength actives like exfoliating acids.Â Good options includeÂ Tower 28 SOS Daily Skin Barrier Redness Recovery MoisturizerÂ orÂ The Ordinary Natural Moisturizing Factors + Hyaluronic Acid.Â Iâ€™mÂ also a fan ofÂ TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s Bio-Active Ceramide Repairing and Plumping Moisturizer.Â 

My top tip for anyone using this serum is to continue using a high-factor, broad-spectrum sunscreen in the daytime because retinoids make skin more sensitive to sunlight. Yep, even in the fall and winter months.Â 

You can always count on TheÂ InkeyÂ List not to leave anyone out, and thereâ€™s good news for retinoid beginners, too. Alongside its buzzy new retinal, the brand has also unveiled aÂ Starter Retinol Serum, just as affordable at $14.Â With 1%Â granactiveÂ retinoid (a gentler, also encapsulatedÂ form) and 0.01% retinal,Â itâ€™sÂ kinder on sensitive skin â€” even for those with rosacea â€” thanks toÂ additionalÂ soothing ingredients like glycerin andÂ symreliefÂ 100Â (made from chamomile and ginger root).Â While itâ€™s pretty new, theÂ five-starÂ reviews speak for themselves.Â 

Where can you get TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™sÂ Advanced 0.2 Retinal?Â 

You can buyÂ The Inkey Listâ€™sÂ Advanced 0.2% RetinalÂ andÂ Starter Retinol SerumÂ fromÂ Sephora.comÂ orÂ join the waitlistÂ on the brandâ€™s website.Â

title: 17 Revamped Haircut Trends Set To Define 2026, According To Top Stylists
text:
17 Revamped Haircut Trends Set To Define 2026, According To Top Stylists

Okay, we arenâ€™t exactly lacking in haircut trends. Recently, we fell for the â€œthickeningâ€ cut â€” a strategically layered style that adds major volume to fine strands â€” and then we spotted the J-shape haircut, with its loose layers that fall effortlessly into that curved silhouette. But with a shiny new year comes a fresh wave of haircut ideas.

Whether youâ€™re eyeing the â€œcloudâ€ bob or craving something shorter, like a pixie crop, thereâ€™s a trend for everyone.

Ahead, top hairstylists from London to NYC share the cuts set to define 2026 â€” and beyond.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Varsity Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by steph hui (@stxph.h)

Hair artist Tom Smith describes the varsity bob as a choppy, chin-skimming cut with subtle layers and a center part. The inspo? Steph Hui and Millie Bobby Brown. â€œPolished but never prissy, it carries a cool collegiate energy â€” youthful without being childish and preppy without being stiff,â€ says Smith. While the movement might look undone, itâ€™s actually intentional and well-maintained, adds Smith, thanks to the invisible layers through the mid-lengths and ends that create that flicky volume.

Gucci Bangs

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Dimitris Giannetos (@dimitrishair)

â€œGucci bangs feel very fashion-forward â€” and powerful,â€ says celebrity hairstylist and colorist, Dimitris Giannetos. He recalls creating the softly-parted, slightly grown-out look for Demi Moore ahead of her role as the fictional character Barbara Gucci in the short film The Tiger. â€œTo achieve this look, ask for wispy curtain bangs just below the brows with face-framing pieces towards the ears,â€ recommends Giannetos. The key? â€œAvoid a blunt cut by adding some variety to the length of the bangs across the face,â€ he says.

The Clean Cut Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Deborah Iona | Beauty & Lifestyle (@deborahiona)

â€œAnok Yaiâ€™s striking short bob, complete with a blunt fringe, highlights the boldness of this style,â€ says celebrity hairdresser Lorraine Dublin. â€œItâ€™s a sharp, chin-skimming bob paired with a clean fringe, and itâ€™s set to stand out this winter.â€ Why? It has a strong, modern silhouette, Dublin explains, yet still feels polished and low-maintenance. We also love the look on content creator Deborah Iona.

The Ripped Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Catherine Gibbs (@ccatherinee.g)

Nick Stenson, celebrity hairstylist and founder of Nick Stenson Beauty, highlights the â€œrippedâ€ bob as the standout cut of winter 2026. â€œBobs are making a comeback because their clean, structured shape offers a chic, low-maintenance look that pairs perfectly with cold-weather layers,â€ says Stenson. The ripped bob, however, is a more interesting, layered take, thanks to softly separated ends created with a texturizing technique where the hair is chopped into vertically. This cut by Catherine Gibbs is perfect.

The Feathered Shag

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair)

The shag is set to take on a much gentler image in 2026, according to Neale Rodger, style director at STIL salon in London. â€œThink soft, feathered layers that build volume and create easy movement,â€ says Rodger, like this look by Ryenne Snow. Rodger adds that itâ€™s the kind of cut that still looks intentional even as it grows out. â€œItâ€™s a brilliant choice for medium to thick hair,â€ continues Rodger, â€œespecially if thereâ€™s already some natural wave or texture to play with.â€ Guiding your stylist is simple: â€œAsk for feathered layers throughout, soft ends, and a length that sits somewhere between the neck and shoulders,â€ advises Rodger.

â€™60s Bangs

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair)

The â€™70s have had their time in the sun. Now, itâ€™s 1960â€™s time to shine, and bangs are leading the resurgence, says Ricky Walters, founder and creative director of Salon 64. â€œThe new incarnation is all about boldness: think thick, heavy, statement-making fringes taken surprisingly far back into the crown,â€ says Walters. He adds, â€œThis isnâ€™t a whisper of a fringe; itâ€™s a full-volume curtain that instantly reshapes the face, adding drama, mystery, and a touch of French-girl rebellion.â€ Walters says that cutting it with plenty of density â€” adding bulk through techniques like point cutting and texturizing â€” prevents it from slipping into anything too dated. Hairstylist Ryenne Snow always nails it.

The Power Pixie

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Iris Law ğŸ§¼ğŸ§Š (@lirisaw)

The power pixie has Florence Pugh, Glenn Close, and Iris Law to thank for its meteoric rise. â€œThis is a cropped, layered pixie thatâ€™s sharp, sculpted, and deliberately androgynous,â€ says Smith. Its key characteristics? â€œEnough length and the top and front to allow for versatile styling,â€ adds Smith, who calls it the ultimate anti-blowout style. â€œThis is great for finer hair types and those who want more lift, as it helps to contour the jawline and cheekbones when long enough to be tucked behind the ears,â€ says Smith. Asking for it couldnâ€™t be simpler: â€œAsk for close layering and texture that can shift from matte and punkish by day to polished and glossy at night,â€ advises Smith â€” and donâ€™t forget the longer, swooping bangs.

The Bubble Cut Blowout

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Dimitris Giannetos (@dimitrishair)

The name sounds complicated, but the result speaks for itself. Itâ€™s essentially a soft blowout with rounded, bouncy ends, explains Giannetos, who recently debuted the look on Amal Clooney. â€œIt works well on long, layered hair, about 6-8 inches from the shoulder. This look enhances body, adds movement, and makes the blowout feel thicker and more voluminous,â€ says Giannetos. â€œI like to take a 1.25â€ Bio Ionic Curler to the ends to lock in the rounded shape.â€

The Polished Pixie

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by SIA | Lifestyle â€¢ Outfits â€¢ Beauty (@sialuxe_)

Super-short styles are still trending, says Dublin, but the polished pixie is having a moment. Just look to content creator Sia. â€œItâ€™s perfect if you want a low-maintenance cut that holds up through the colder, wetter months,â€ Dublin says, adding, â€œIf youâ€™re not ready for a full chop, a pixie-style wig gives you the same look with zero commitment.â€

The Shaggy Bob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Akesha Reid (@keeksreid)

The shaggy bob is not only effortlessly chic, says Dublin, but itâ€™s practical for winter and spring. â€œThe layers add movement and texture â€” great under scarves or hats â€” while still looking polished for work or evening plans,â€ adds Dublin. Grab a hydrating hair cream like PATTERN by Tracee Ellis Ross Palo Santo Styling Cream and let your natural texture do its thing. This cut on Keeks Reid is beautiful.Â 

The Modern Shag

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by SHAG! (@shaglondon)

Mussed-up texture is in this season, says Stenson, and while the classic shagâ€™s layering technique is making a comeback, itâ€™s being reimagined for 2026 with modern softness and volume. â€œEven better, itâ€™s flexible across hair types,â€ he adds. â€œA shag is great for anyone with thick hair because it removes weight and bulk.
